selected_quotes: Blond hair in Melanesians a result of #genetic #mutation
5/4/12: Melanesian Blond Hair Is Caused by an Amino Acid Change in TYRP1 (blond Melanesians carry 2 copies of gene)
Finding the gene for blond hair in Melanesians. Really cool work
@annenonniemoss Blonde hair is a natural recessive trait for blacks due to a mutation in the TYRP1 gene long ago.
Blond hair evolved TWICE! Knew we were special!

citation.abstract: Naturally blond hair is rare in humans and found almost exclusively in Europe and Oceania. Here, we identify an arginine-to-cysteine change at a highly conserved residue in tyrosinase-related protein 1 (TYRP1) as a major determinant of blond hair in Solomon Islanders. This missense mutation is predicted to affect catalytic activity of TYRP1 and causes blond hair through a recessive mode of inheritance. The mutation is at a frequency of 26% in the Solomon Islands, is absent outside of Oceania, represents a strong common genetic effect on a complex human phenotype, and highlights the importance of examining genetic associations worldwide.
citation.publisher: American Association for the Advancement of Science
citation.title: Melanesian Blond Hair Is Caused by an Amino Acid Change in TYRP1

wikipedia.title: Blond
wikipedia.summary: Blond or blonde (see below), or fair hair, is a hair color characterized by low levels of the dark pigment eumelanin.

wikipedia.summary: Mark Stoneking (born 1 August 1956) is a geneticist currently working as the Group Leader of the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology, of Max Planck Gesellschaft at Leipzig, and Honorary Professor of Biological Anthropology, University of Lei

wikipedia.title: Solomon Islands
wikipedia.summary: Solomon Islands is a sovereign country consisting of a large number of islands in Oceania lying to the east of Papua New Guinea and northwest of Vanuatu and covering a land area of .

wikipedia.title: Melanesians
wikipedia.summary: Melanesians are the dominant inhabitants of Melanesia. Most speak one of the many Papuan languages, though a few groups such as Moluccans, the Motu and Fijians speak Austronesian languages.
